Sorbonne-ENGL-101-Syllabus-Academic-Writ.title: Sorbonne ENGL 101 Syllabus – Academic Writing
Sorbonne-ENGL-101-Syllabus-Academic-Writ.content:
Sorbonne ENGL 101 Syllabus Academic Writing
Course Description
This course develops academic writing, reading, and critical thinking skills. Students practice the full writing process, learn research methods, and build the foundation for university-level communication.
Learning Outcomes

Produce clear, coherent academic prose.
Construct thesis-driven writings in exploratory, analytical, and argumentative forms.
Read critically, summarize, paraphrase, and respond to texts.
Locate, evaluate, and integrate academic sources responsibly.
Apply the writing process: planning, drafting, revising, editing.
Produce a research-supported argumentative writing.
Present research findings in an organized oral format.

Major Assignments

Writing 1: Exploratory Writing (500 words)
Writing 2: Textual/Rhetorical Analysis (800 words)
Writing 3: Research Argument (800 words)
Research Presentation (5–10 minutes)
Final Portfolio (Revisions + Reflective Writing)

Assignments
Writing 1: Exploratory Writing (500 words - 20% of grade)
Purpose: Develop clear structure and reflective exploratory writing.
Task: Write an exploratory piece of writing related to the theme of the class that shapes your perspective.
Requirements:

Clear controlling idea
Narrative detail and reflection
Logical structure
Edited for clarity and grammar

Writing 2: Textual/Rhetorical Analysis (800 words - 30% of grade)
Purpose: Strengthen critical reading and analytical writing.
Task: Analyze how an author persuades an audience. Focus on rhetorical strategies.
Requirements:

Thesis with analytical claim
Use of rhetorical frameworks
Evidence from text (quotes/paraphrase)
Focus on how the text persuades

Writing 3: Research-Supported Argument (800 words - 30% of grade)
Purpose: Produce an original argument using credible sources.
Task: Answer a focused research question using 3–5 academic or high-quality sources.
Requirements:

Clear argument and counterargument
Integrate sources with citations
Logical organization
Academic tone

Presentation (5–10 minutes - 10% of grade)
Purpose: Present an original idea from research related to the theme of the class.
Requirements:

Explain research question, thesis, and main points
Discuss supporting evidence
Address one counterargument
Use slides or visual aids if needed

Final Portfolio (10% of grade)
Purpose: Demonstrate growth across the course through revision and reflection.
Task: Compile and revise your best work from the semester, along with a reflective essay about your writing development and learning journey.
Requirements:

Include revised versions of Writing 1, Writing 2, and Writing 3 as required
Write a 200-word reflective essay about your growth as a writer in this course
Demonstrate improvement in writing quality and skill by providing all work
Proper formatting and organization of all portfolio elements


Schedule
Week 1: Orientation & Diagnostic

Course overview and expectations
Academic integrity introduction
Diagnostic writing task

Week 2: Academic Reading & Paragraph Skills

Active reading strategies
Summary writing
Paragraph structure and cohesion
Short summary exercise

Week 3: Writing Fundamentals

Thesis development
Writing structure
Writing 1 outline exercise

Week 4: Drafting Writing 1

Drafting workshop
Peer review
Revision strategies
Submit Writing 1

Week 5: Introduction to Rhetorical Analysis

Purpose, audience, tone
Ethos, pathos, logos
In-class rhetorical analysis task

Week 6: Critical Reading & Analytical Writing

Identifying claims, assumptions, evidence
Analytical response assignment

Week 7: Planning Writing 2

Close reading techniques
Rhetorical frameworks (SOAP, rhetorical triangle)
Writing 2 proposal

Week 8: Drafting Writing 2

Integrating quotations and commentary
Peer review and revision
Submit Writing 2

Week 9: Research Foundations

Research questions and keywords
Library/database strategies
Research exploration

Week 10: Evaluating Sources & Citation Skills

Source credibility evaluation
Paraphrasing and avoiding plagiarism

Week 11: Argument Structure

Claims, reasons, evidence
Counterargument strategies
Writing 3 argument mindmap

Week 12: Drafting Writing 3

Synthesizing sources
Long-form blueprint structure
Submit Writing 3

Week 13: Research Presentations

Presentation guidelines
In-class presentations

Week 14: Revision & Portfolio Preparation

Portfolio revision planning

Week 15: Portfolio Workshop

Revision support-

Week 16: Final Portfolio Submission

Submit Portfolio

Course Policies
Attendance: Active engagement is expected in all sessions.
Academic Integrity: All submitted work must be original and properly cited.
Late Work: May be penalized unless approved in advance.
Accessibility: Students requiring accommodations should contact Student Affairs.
Required Materials

Instructor-selected readings
Academic articles and excerpts
Recommended writing handbook

Sorbonne-ENGL-102-Writing-in-the-Humanit.filePath: Sorbonne ENGL 102 Writing in the Humanities.md
Sorbonne-ENGL-102-Writing-in-the-Humanit.title: Sorbonne ENGL102 Writing in the Humanities
Sorbonne-ENGL-102-Writing-in-the-Humanit.content:
Sorbonne ENGL 102 Writing in the Humanities
Course Description
This course helps military cadets improve their writing skills while learning about leadership through interesting stories, movies, and real-world examples. Students will read short articles, watch clips from films, and write essays about leadership within the humanities, in history, literature, and modern life. The focus is on clear communication and understanding what makes a good leader.
Learning Outcomes

Read and understand leadership stories and articles.
Write clear essays about leadership topics.
Discuss leadership ideas in class.
Analyze what makes leaders successful or unsuccessful.

Major Assessments

Essay 1: My Favorite Leader (500 words)
Essay 2: Learning from Mistakes (800 words)
Essay 3: Leadership Today (1000 words)
Final Reflection (200 words)
Weekly Activities and Class Participation

Assignments
Writing 1: An Interesting Leader** (500 words - 20% of grade)
Purpose: Develop personal connection to leadership concepts through admiration and analysis.
Task: Write about a leader you admire and explain why. Use examples from class readings or films.
Requirements:

Clear description of the leader and their qualities
Specific examples from course materials
Personal reflection on why this leader inspires you
Well-organized structure with clear introduction and conclusion

Writing 2: Learning from Mistakes (800 words - 30% of grade)
Purpose: Analyze leadership failures to understand what not to do and recovery possibilities.
Task: Analyze a leader who made a serious mistake. What did they do wrong and what can we learn?
Requirements:

Detailed analysis of the leader’s mistake
Critical evaluation of the consequences
Lessons learned and applications to modern leadership
Proper use of course readings and film examples

Writing 3: Leadership Today (1000 words - 30% of grade)
Purpose: Compare historical and contemporary leadership to understand evolution and adaptation.
Task: Compare leadership in the past to leadership today. Use examples from course materials.
Requirements:

Clear comparison between past and present leadership
Use of multiple course examples and sources
Analysis of what has changed and what remains constant
Conclusion about effective leadership across time periods

Presentation (5–10 minutes - 10% of grade)
Purpose: Present an original idea from research related to the theme of the class.
Requirements:

Explain research question, thesis, and main points
Discuss supporting evidence
Address one counterargument
Use slides or visual aids if needed

Final Portfolio (10% of grade)
Purpose: Synthesize learning and personal growth throughout the course.
Task: Write about what you learned about leadership and yourself in this course.
Requirements:

Personal insights about leadership development
Write a 200-word description of leadership, as addressed in this class
Connection to your own leadership goals
Reflection on course impact and changed perspectives
Clear and concise writing


Schedule
Week 1: Orientation & Leadership Basics

Course overview and expectations
Introduction to leadership concepts
“A Leader I Know” personal writing exercise
Discussion: Leaders you know and admire

Week 2: Historical Leadership Inspiration

Reading: How Eisenhower’s Crisis Management Strategies Will Help You Master the Art of Leadership
Film: “The King’s Speech” (selected parts)
Writing: Compare two leaders exercise
Discussion: How do leaders inspire people?

Week 3: Modern Leadership Context

Reading: Government Leaders, What Makes a Leader?
Film: Clips about modern business leaders
Writing: Essay 1 draft workshop
Discussion: Can anyone be a leader?

Week 4: Inspiring Others

Reading: 3 Ways to Motivate Your Team Through an Extended Crisis
Film: “Invictus” (reconciliation leadership parts)
Writing: Essay 1 revision workshop
Discussion: What motivates you to follow a leader?

Week 5: Leadership in Difficult Times

Reading: Leadership Lessons From the Wartime General, Leadership in Crisis: 10 Key Strategies
Film: “Saving Private Ryan” (leadership scenes)
Writing: Submit Essay 1: My Favorite Leader
Discussion: When is it okay to make unpopular decisions?

Week 6: UAE Leadership Context

Reading: UAE Centennial 2071
Film: Documentary about UAE development
Writing: Personal reflection on UAE leadership
Discussion: How does UAE leadership reflect its culture?

Week 7: Understanding Leadership Mistakes

Reading: Why Good Leaders Fail, Strategies for Learning from Failure
Film: “The Social Network” (leadership challenges)
Writing: Essay 2 planning workshop
Discussion: Why do good leaders sometimes fail?

Week 8: Ethics in Leadership

Reading: A New Model for Ethical Leadership, A Framework for Ethical Decision Making
Film: “Letters from Iwo Jima” (honor across cultures)
Writing: Essay 2 workshop and peer review
Discussion: What would you do in this situation?

Week 9: Recovery and Redemption

Reading: How to Turn Setbacks into Comebacks, Redemption in Leadership: Lessons for Workplace Growth
Film: Clips about resilience and recovery
Writing: Submit Essay 2: Learning from Mistakes
Discussion: Is redemption possible for leaders?

Week 10: Team Leadership

Reading: Google re:Work - Understand Team Effectiveness, Army Leaders Discuss Readiness, Teamwork
Film: “Apollo 13” (team leadership)
Writing: Essay 3 planning workshop
Discussion: What makes a good team leader?

Week 11: Leadership in the Digital Age

Reading: Leadership Development “Hacks” from Silicon Valley, The New Elements of Digital Transformation
Film: Clips about modern innovation
Writing: Essay 3 draft workshop
Discussion: How has technology changed leadership?

Week 12: Global Leadership

Reading: Cross-cultural Leadership
Film: Documentary about global leaders
Writing: Submit Essay 3: Leadership Today
Discussion: What makes a leader work across cultures?

Week 13: Leadership in the UAE Context

Reading: Federal Youth Authority
Film: “The Message” (Islamic leadership principles)
Writing: Final reflection planning
Discussion: What kind of leader do you want to be?

Week 14: Course Reflection and Future Goals

Course summary and learning synthesis
Sharing favorite insights from the course
Peer feedback on essays and final reflection
Submit Final Reflection
Discussion: Your leadership goals for the future

Course Policies
Attendance: Required - Military training values discipline. More than 3 absences may affect your grade. Contact instructor if you miss class due to military duties.
Academic Integrity: All submitted work must be original and properly cited.
Late Work: May be penalized unless approved in advance.
Accessibility: Students requiring accommodations should contact Student Affairs.
Required Materials

Simple Leadership Stories - Collection of easy-to-read articles
UAE Leadership Examples - Stories about UAE leaders
Historical Leadership Tales - Brief stories about famous leaders
Modern Leadership Articles - Current leadership examples
“The King’s Speech” (selected scenes)
“Saving Private Ryan” (leadership scenes)
“Invictus” (reconciliation leadership)
“Apollo 13” (team leadership)
Short documentary clips about UAE leaders
TED Talks about leadership (simple versions)
Basic Writing Handbook - Simple grammar and style guide
Essay Writing Templates - Step-by-step essay structure
Citation Guide - How to give credit to sources


Reading Materials Integration Summary
✅ 19 validated readings successfully integrated across weeks 2-13

Week 2: How Eisenhower’s Crisis Management Strategies Will Help You Master the Art of Leadership (Entrepreneur)
Week 3: Government Leaders (UAE), What Makes a Leader? (HBR)
Week 4: 3 Ways to Motivate Your Team Through an Extended Crisis (HBR)
Week 5: Leadership Lessons From the Wartime General (Newsweek), Leadership in Crisis: 10 Key Strategies (CCL)
Week 6: UAE Centennial 2071 (UAE Government)
Week 7: Why Good Leaders Fail (MIT Sloan), Strategies for Learning from Failure (HBR)
Week 8: A New Model for Ethical Leadership (HBR), A Framework for Ethical Decision Making (Santa Clara)
Week 9: How to Turn Setbacks into Comebacks, Redemption in Leadership: Lessons for Workplace Growth
Week 10: Google re:Work - Understand Team Effectiveness, Army Leaders Discuss Readiness, Teamwork
Week 11: Leadership Development “Hacks” from Silicon Valley, The New Elements of Digital Transformation
Week 12: Cross-cultural Leadership (IMD)
Week 13: Federal Youth Authority (UAE Federal Youth Authority)

Content Appropriateness Analysis Summary:
✅ ALL READINGS ARE APPROPRIATE for their assigned weeks:

Week 2: Historical leadership - Eisenhower crisis management perfect fit
Week 3: Modern leadership context - UAE leaders + HBR article ideal
Week 4: Inspiring/motivation - Crisis motivation article aligns well
Week 5: Crisis leadership - Wartime + crisis articles excellent match
Week 6: UAE leadership - Vision 2071 perfect fit
Week 7: Leadership mistakes - Failure analysis articles appropriate
Week 8: Ethics - Leadership ethics articles perfect fit
Week 9: Recovery/redemption - Comeback + redemption articles ideal
Week 10: Team leadership - Google + Army teamwork excellent match
Week 11: Digital age - Tech leadership + transformation perfect fit
Week 12: Global leadership - Cross-cultural leadership ideal
Week 13: UAE youth leadership - Federal Youth Authority perfect match

All links validated via Playwright (December 12, 2025)

ZMU-ENGL-102-The-Emirates-Past-Present-F.filePath: ZMU ENGL 102 The Emirates Past Present Future.md
ZMU-ENGL-102-The-Emirates-Past-Present-F.title: ZMU ENGL102 The Emirates: Past, Present, Future
ZMU-ENGL-102-The-Emirates-Past-Present-F.content:
ZMU ENGL 102 The Emirates Past Present Future
Course Description
This course helps military cadets learn about the United Arab Emirates through stories, videos, and discussions. Students will explore how the UAE grew from a small desert region to a modern nation, and think about what the future might look like. The focus is on writing clearly about UAE’s journey and thinking about your role in its future.
Course Learning Outcomes
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Understand UAE’s history and how it became successful
Write about UAE’s development in clear, simple essays
Think about the future and what it means for them as leaders
Connect past, present, and future to see how they fit together

Assignments (70% of final grade)
Essay 1: UAE’s Amazing Story (350 words)
Write about how the UAE changed from the past to today. Use examples from class materials.
Due: Week 5
Essay 2: UAE Today - What’s Special? (450 words)
Describe what makes the UAE special today. Compare it to other countries.
Due: Week 9
Essay 3: My Vision for UAE’s Future (550 words)
Think about the UAE in 20 years. What will it be like? What will you contribute?
Due: Week 12
Final Reflection (250 words)
Write about what you learned about the UAE and yourself in this course.
Due: Week 14
Weekly Activities (30% of final grade)

Short weekly reflections (100 words each)
Video discussions about UAE
Group projects about UAE topics
Class participation


Schedule
Unit 1: UAE Past - How It All Started (Weeks 1-3)
Week 1: Life Before the UAE
Focus: Understanding life in the old UAE

Readings:

Simple story about life in the desert
Article about pearl diving and traditional life


Film: Documentary clips about old UAE
Writing: “What I Know About Old UAE” (personal knowledge)
Discussion: What do you know about UAE’s past?

Week 2: Sheikh Zayed’s Vision
Focus: How one leader changed everything

Readings:

Story about Sheikh Zayed’s ideas
Simple explanation of UAE formation


Film: Documentary about UAE founding
Writing: Compare old UAE to new UAE
Discussion: What was Sheikh Zayed’s biggest contribution?

Week 3: Building the Nation
Focus: How the UAE was created

Readings:

Article about the 1971 formation
Story about bringing emirates together


Film: Clips about early UAE development
Writing: Essay 1 planning
Discussion: Why was it important to unite the emirates?


Unit 2: UAE Present - Success Today (Weeks 4-6)
Week 4: From Oil to Innovation
Focus: How UAE moved beyond oil

Readings:

Simple article about UAE’s economy
Story about Dubai’s growth


Film: “Dubai: Beyond Oil” documentary
Writing: Essay 1 draft workshop
Discussion: What makes UAE’s economy different?

Week 5: UAE as a Leader
Focus: How UAE leads in the region

Readings:

Article about UAE’s international role
Story about UAE’s space program


Film: Mars Mission highlights
Writing: Submit Essay 1: UAE’s Amazing Story
Discussion: How does UAE help other countries?

Week 6: Culture and Tradition
Focus: Balancing old and new in UAE

Readings:

Article about UAE culture
Story about modern Emiratis


Film: Clips about UAE festivals and traditions
Writing: Personal reflection on UAE identity
Discussion: How does UAE keep its culture while modernizing?


Unit 3: UAE Present - Modern Success (Weeks 7-9)
Week 7: Innovation and Technology
Focus: UAE as a tech leader

Readings:

Article about UAE’s smart cities
Story about digital government


Film: “Smart Dubai” documentary
Writing: Essay 2 planning
Discussion: How does technology make life better?

Week 8: Global Connections
Focus: UAE’s place in the world

Readings:

Article about UAE’s international relationships
Story about Expo 2020 Dubai


Film: Highlights from Expo 2020
Writing: Essay 2 workshop
Discussion: Why do other countries visit UAE?

Week 9: Youth and Education
Focus: UAE’s young people and their future

Readings:

Article about UAE education
Story about young Emiratis


Film: Clips about UAE universities and innovation
Writing: Submit Essay 2: UAE Today - What’s Special?
Discussion: What opportunities does UAE give young people?


Unit 4: UAE Future - What’s Next? (Weeks 10-12)
Week 10: Vision 2071
Focus: UAE’s plan for the future

Readings:

Simple explanation of Vision 2071
Article about UAE’s goals


Film: “UAE 2071” documentary
Writing: Essay 3 planning
Discussion: What do you want UAE to be like in 50 years?

Week 11: Environment and Sustainability
Focus: UAE’s green future

Readings:

Article about UAE’s environmental goals
Story about renewable energy


Film: “Green UAE” documentary
Writing: Essay 3 draft workshop
Discussion: How can UAE help solve environmental problems?

Week 12: Leadership in the Future
Focus: Your role as future leaders

Readings:

Article about future leaders
Story about youth and leadership


Film: Clips about young leaders
Writing: Submit Essay 3: My Vision for UAE’s Future
Discussion: What kind of leader does UAE need?


Unit 5: Your Role in UAE’s Future (Weeks 13-14)
Week 13: Contributing to UAE
Focus: How you can help UAE succeed

Readings:

Article about serving your country
Story about military service


Film: “Service to Nation” documentary
Writing: Final reflection planning
Discussion: How will you contribute to UAE?

Week 14: Course Reflection
Focus: What did you learn about UAE and yourself?

Activities:

Share favorite insights about UAE
Discuss how course changed your perspective
Peer feedback on essays


Writing: Final Reflection Submission
Discussion: Your commitment to UAE’s future


Required Course Materials
Reading Materials (All Provided Free)

UAE History Stories - Simple stories about UAE’s past
UAE Today Articles - Current information about UAE
Vision 2071 Materials - Easy explanations of UAE’s future plans
Leadership Examples - Stories about UAE leaders

Videos and Films

Documentary: “The Story of UAE”
Documentary: “Dubai: Beyond Oil”
Documentary: “UAE Space Program”
Documentary: “Expo 2020 Dubai”
Documentary: “Vision 2071”
Short clips about UAE culture and achievements

Writing Resources

UAE Facts Handbook - Important information about UAE
Essay Writing Templates - Simple essay structure guides
Timeline of UAE - Important dates and events
Citation Guide - How to credit sources


Grading System
Essay Grading (Simple 4-Point Scale)

Excellent - Clear ideas, good examples, shows understanding of UAE
Good - Clear main points, some examples, shows understanding
Needs Improvement - Some good ideas but unclear about UAE
Poor - Unclear ideas, missing examples, shows little understanding

Class Participation

Coming prepared with readings completed
Contributing to discussions about UAE
Participating in group activities
Showing respect for UAE culture and values


Course Policies
Attendance

Required - Important for understanding UAE culture
More than 3 absences may affect your grade
Contact instructor if you miss class due to military duties

Assignments

Due dates are firm - late work gets lower grades
Revisions allowed - You can improve essays after feedback
Original work only - No copying or plagiarism

Getting Help

Writing Center - Free tutoring available
UAE Studies resources - Extra materials about UAE
Office hours - Talk to instructor one-on-one
Arabic support - Help with Arabic sources if needed


Student Support
Academic Help

Writing tutors familiar with UAE content
Research assistance for UAE topics
Study groups with other cadets

Military Life Support

Flexible scheduling for training requirements
Leadership connections to UAE military
Service learning opportunities

UAE Culture Support

Cultural explanations for complex topics
Local examples throughout the course
Vision 2071 workshops for future planning
Leadership mentoring program


Grade Breakdown



































AssignmentPercentageDescriptionEssay 120%UAE’s Amazing Story (350 words)Essay 225%UAE Today - What’s Special? (450 words)Essay 325%My Vision for UAE’s Future (550 words)Final Reflection15%Course Summary (250 words)Class Participation15%Discussions, activities, attendance
